Financial Stress Composite Signal

Systemic stress from credit spreads, curve inversion, and financial conditions.

As of Unknown

Gemini Summary

Signal Summary:

  • The Financial Stress Composite signal (1) indicates Neutral financial conditions as of 2025-12-31, with a composite z-score of -0.539878.
  • This reflects a period of stability in credit and funding markets, with a slight bias towards less stressful conditions.
  • Conviction Band: Medium, Interpretation Confidence: High Confidence, Internal Conflict Flag: No.

Key Dynamics:

  • The z-score for High-Yield Option-Adjusted Spreads (HY_OAS) is -0.917506, signaling Low_Stress conditions for this component (1).
  • The St. Louis Fed Financial Stress Index (STLFSI4) z-score is -0.452791, and the inverted 10Y2Y Treasury Yield Spread z-score is -0.249338, both also indicating lower-than-average stress (1).
  • All three components consistently point to easing or neutral stress levels, driving the composite into the lower end of the Neutral regime.
  • Conditional Invalidation: The composite z-score rising above +0.75 would indicate a shift to High_Stress.

Scenario Balance:

  • Base Case dominant: Financial conditions remain Neutral, as the composite value is firmly within the defined bounds of normal functioning.
  • Upside secondary: Conditions ease further towards a Low_Stress regime, potentially driven by tighter credit spreads.
  • Downside residual: A notable increase in systemic stress or yield curve inversion pushes the composite into High_Stress.

Time Horizon & Aggregation:

  • Time Horizon: Cyclical (months), as financial stress indicators typically reflect macro-economic cycles.
  • Aggregation Weight Hint: Medium, given its high confidence in assessing overall financial conditions.

Macro Relevance:

  • This signal primarily informs macro dimensions of Liquidity and Credit, providing insights into the cost and availability of capital.
  • Current Neutral conditions suggest a mid-cycle environment, where financial markets are functioning without acute stress.
  • It interacts with demand (via credit availability), asset pricing (risk premiums), and broader sentiment, influencing growth expectations.

Data & References:

  • St. Louis Fed Financial Stress Index (STLFSI4), latest 2025-12-31 (1).
  • ICE BofA U.S. High-Yield Option-Adjusted Spread (HY_OAS), latest 2025-12-31 (1).
  • 10-Year minus 2-Year Treasury Yield Spread (T10Y2Y), latest 2025-12-31 (1).
  • The HY_OAS z-score has been particularly influential, indicating a strong move towards easier credit conditions.
  • Two additional public datasets that would improve depth or reliability are the Market Volatility (VIX) Signal (2) for equity market stress and the Private Credit Impulse Signal (3) for credit growth dynamics.
